turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: DOMA was signed into law by President Bill Clinton on September 21, 1996.

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: Section 2 allowed states to refuse to recognize same-sex marriages granted under the laws of other states.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: The Act had two main components: Section 2 and Section 3.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: However, Section 3 of DOMA was struck down as unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court in the 2013 case of United States v. Windsor.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: Section 3 defined marriage for federal purposes as the union of one man and one woman, which effectively barred same-sex married couples from receiving federal marriage benefits.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: This ruling effectively allowed same-sex married couples to be recognized as "spouses" for purposes of federal laws and to receive federal marriage benefits.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent

turn2_selected_sentences.sentence: DOMA was passed by large, veto-proof majorities in both houses of Congress and was initially intended by Congress to reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality.
turn2_selected_sentences.speaker: agent
